title.narrative: OUTPUT 3.1 HEALTH ENABLING ENVIROMENT

description.narrative: By 2024, health sector policy, plans and budgets use solid evidence to strengthen the health system for child and maternal survival., which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Early Childhood Development, Hiv Prevention, Immunization, Maternal And Newborn Health. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2024: Significantly more girls, boys, adolescents and women, especially those who are marginalized and/or living in humanitarian conditions, have access to and utilize evidence-based, high-impact quality maternal, neonatal, child, adolescent health, and HIV interventions.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2024, health sector policy, plans and budgets use solid evidence to strengthen the health system for child and maternal survival.

description.narrative: By June 2020 implementation of the Rolling Workplan implementation has reached 50% with improvement in key indicators ( children vaccinated with Penta 3 increased to 74% against a target of 88% for 2020. Furthermore, children treated for pneumonia in remote communities increased to 95% against a target of 55% for 2020. Other indicators that has made progress are: Birth attended by skilled health workers 64% against 55% target while newborn receiving postnatal is at 61% against 55% target. Other key indicators that made improvement by mid-2020 are: pregnant women positive of HIV and accessing treatment at 57% against 50% target. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/08/2020

title.narrative: Existence of a Multi-Year Plan (MYP) for immunisation
